section.title: Purpose
section.para: The main purpose of this Note is to define a method and a template to collect Physical Science use cases from scientists and research engineers working on Physical Science projects in the context and within the scope of the OpenPOWER Foundation for Physical Science Workgroup.
An effective method (shared between all stakeholders) could contribute to

listitem.para: understand the workflow, starting with user expectations;
help Physical Science projects maintain costs within a chosen envelope;
map the functionalities to the scientific requirements;
remove the misunderstanding between scientific community and ICT stakeholders.

section.para: Section h.fjazhaptp3e8 describes the context and the main OPFPS workflow. The proposed method is a template reported in Section h.bj00l8vcud7l and justified in Section h.d31180cwfjew.

section.title: Scope
section.para: This OPFPS WG should contribute, with the foreseen deliverables (WP2, WP3 and WP4) (see [1]), in a more effective process of managing the increasing complexity of a Physical Science projects, because this could help to take the ICT system under control or to find new solutions that are at the corner of the ICT industry.

section.title: Stakeholders identification
section.para: This section describes the intended audience of this Note and of the OPFPS WG.

Stakeholders are individuals, groups, organizations who are actively involved in the scientific project, are affected by its outcome or are able to influence its outcome. All stakeholders could be OPFPS members. The stakeholders are:

listitem.para: Physical Science community: stakeholders that should provide requirements:
Scientists
Research engineers
ICT community: stakeholders that could provide a solution
WG participants: members of both community that should provide support in collecting, analyzing and categorizing requirements.

section.title: Acronyms
section.para: OPFPS = OpenPOWER Foundation for Physical Science

listitem.para: Problem analysis: Problem analysis involves identifying the overriding problem and establishing the causes and effects related to that problem.
Scientific objectives: The scientific objectives are the goals of a scientific project. The scientific requirements are needed to reach the scientific objectives.

Scientific requirements A) are high-level statements that are needed to reach the scientific objectives/goals of the scientific project (and of the scientific organisation that manage the project). They describe the results that the project will achieve, and the metrics which will be used to measure its success. Scientific requirements must be achieved to provide value for the scientific project. B) A requirement of a physical science experiment described in terms of the parameters to perform science (e.g. minimum sensitivity of a telescope, minimum angular resolution).
Example: we need to observe N celestial objects in T time.
Example: we need to repoint the telescope in 30 seconds.

System requirements: requirements of the HW/SW solution, i.e. the functional and non-functional requirements of the proposed system. Functional requirements define a function or a behaviour of a system (a list of the major features or user capabilities unique to the product). Non-functional requirements impose qualities and constraints on the design or implementation (such as performance, security, or reliability).
System: the solution that should be proposed/developed.

section.title: Physical Science
section.para: Physical Science is any science concerned with nonliving matter, energy, and the physical properties of the Universe, such as physics, chemistry, astronomy, and geology.

section.para: The proposed process is iterative, so that reference solutions can be reworked in the light of increased knowledge. Iteration means that the scientific stakeholders should provide use cases and non-functional requirements and refine them based on feedbacks received by other stakeholders or by the OPFPS members.

listitem.para: The OPFPS members are available to update the common workflow for each new use case that is added or updated.

section.title: Method

listitem.para: Description of the scientific problem and related scientific requirements: In this context, the WG asks scientific stakeholders to provide an overview/summary of their problem (with a short description of the scientific objectives), and to provide scientific requirements that could be measurable; this helps to identify the scientific requirements for which a possible HW/SW solution has the greatest impact. The main purpose is to provide a real value of the proposed solution to the users;
Definition of use cases and identification of system requirements (functional and non-functional) that are used as input to define a solution.

section.para: The main purpose is to identify system functional and system non-functional requirements that provide real value for the scientific project, i.e. to help to fulfill scientific requirements. System functional requirements define a function or a behaviour of a system. System non-functional requirements impose qualities and constraints on the design or implementation of the system (such as performance, security, or reliability).

In Section h.hifw4g34594y we report the template, that reflects the two steps depicted above. Sections h.ivq40yd8cvjz, h.z8a4r4bndbdc and h.k1sz7cwj362y report a justification of the template. Section h.okc3b56431x4 is a summary.

section.title: The template
section.para: Scientists, research engineers, hardware and software developers and vendors do not have a common language and terms; all WG participants need details and guidance that organise the information in a uniform way. For the purpose of this work the use cases must be readable by all involved stakeholders.

In this section we propose a template to collect Physical Science use cases from scientific stakeholders. This template could help to collect problem statements and solution requirements. With this template we will help stakeholders to extract useful information from their “problem” to better understand:

listitem.para: which scientific requirement the proposed solution should fulfill and
to better identify use cases/workflows/functional requirements and the context;
to enable solutions with a real benefit for scientists.

section.para: The template is organized in sections and where some key questions or suggestions are presents.
The following sections report a justification of the template.

section.title: Problem analysis and scientific requirements
section.para: It is important to have a summary of the problem that the scientific project covers/wants to resolve. The scientific stakeholders should extract some basic information from their problem domain.

The section “Scientific problem analysis” helps OPFPS members and ICT stakeholders to focus on useful information from the problem domain of the scientific project. In fact, this is a basic problem analysis procedure that help OPF members and ICT stakeholders to identify the real value for scientists in the resolution of their problems.
The first step is the identification of scientific objectives, i.e. the goals of the scientific project (section “Scientific objectives”).

The scientific requirements are needed to reach the scientific objectives. The scientific stakeholders should identify the scientific requirements of the project (in analogy with the “business requirements” for an enterprise) for which the proposed solution has the maximum impact, and to provide a metric that will be used to measure the effectiveness of the proposed solution (section “Scientific requirements and problem definition”).

The primary reason products/systems don’t help to improve/satisfy the right scientific requirements is because the scientific requirements have not been identified adequately or they have not been properly understood by the ICT stakeholders (section “Underlying causes of a problem”).
This step will help to define a reference solution for a workflow/system that will provide a real value for the scientific project (section “Benefits of a solution”).
For a justification of the problem analysis, and the impact on the requirement inception see Section h.it0ht7pktu33

section.para: With the scientific requirements in mind the scientific stakeholders should define the system requirements of the HW/SW solution, i.e. the functional and non-functional requirements of the proposed system.
These are the main information about the product/solution:

listitem.para:
Product Vision: describes what the product is (section “Vision of the solution”).

Project Scope: identifies what portion of the ultimate scientific project the current product/system will address, definition of solution system boundaries. A context diagram could be provided that shows a top-level view of a system and the system’s boundaries (section “Scope”).
Provide clear statements of assumptions (section “Assumptions”).

Functional requirements: It is possible to describe the solution in term of a workflow, a list of functional requirement or a use case (sections h.4d2bodt7akfe). List the major features or user capabilities unique to the new product. For non-functional requirements check section h.lqcugjv94utp for more details. See section “Description of the workflow/main functional and non-functional requirements”.
Identify the constraints: put limitations on the ability to deliver a solution as envisioned restricting the solution space (section “Constraints”).

section.title: The system (the solution)
section.para: The system, for which we collect system requirements could be a workflow or a dataflow (or part of a workflow) of a solution for a scientific project, a software library of a software framework that could be used as part of a workflow or a dataflow.

section.title: In a nutshell
section.para: With use cases/workflow/list of system requirements we describe a possible workflow/dataflow of a system and/or software library of a scientific project, using the template.
The workflow is a view of the functional requirements of the system, with attached system non-functional requirements.
A system could be a data analysis system or a software library/framework that covers some system requirements.

The proposed solution is a possibile solution, using OPF hardware and software, that implement a system of a scientific project, or that optimize an existing solution, or that optimize the use of software libraries/framework used/developed by the scientific community
The proposed solution contributes to achieving the scientific requirements of a scientific project.

section.title: Justifications
section.para: In this section are provided the reasons for using the proposed method.

section.title: Requirement inception for a Physical Science project
section.para: Before system requirements can be analyzed, modeled, or specified they must be gathered through an elicitation process.
An effective process of requirement inception (shared between all stakeholders) could contribute and therefore to

listitem.para: understand the workflow, starting with user expectations;

help Physical Science projects maintain costs within a chosen envelope, helping to decide what/which ICT system to build, what the system must do, how it must behave (in the context of the general Physical Science project workflow), the properties it must exhibit, the qualities it must possess, and the constraints that the system and its development must satisfy;
map the functionalities to the scientific requirements.

section.para: Physical Science projects are at the corner of the Physical Science (to open new windows in the scientific domain) and for this reason are at the corner of the current technology, or (more common) new technology should be developed to fulfill the requirements. With this in mind, a requirement inception process is a challenge because there are many different problems that the OPFPS members should manage to remove the misunderstanding between scientific and ICT stakeholders:

listitem.para: Problem of scope:

the user (scientist/research engineer) specifies too many technical details with the risk to loose the functional aspect of their problem, and this implies a poor understanding of the functional requirements, i.e. of the workflow;
and/or the boundary of the system is not well defined;
to mix functional and non-functional requirements.
Problem of understanding: some of them could came from
have trouble communicating needs to the hw/sw developers/vendors,
omit information that is believed to be “obvious”,
specify requirements that conflicts.

Problem of presumption: Presumptions: an assumption, an an idea that is taken to be true, and often used as the basis for other ideas, although it is not known for certain. In our context this presumption could be made by the scientific stakeholders or by who is collection requirements (WG members), usually when some aspect of the problem domain are not well known or understood.
Requirements volatility: the requirements change over time (see Section h.4lpolzhmiyzr).

section.para: A Physical Science project has no similar examples that could be followed, due to its uniqueness. The current experiments help us in collecting experience, but sometimes new Physical Science projects are one order of magnitude bigger than current scientific projects (e.g. Big Science Projects).

section.title: Volatility
section.para: This section is for ICT stakeholders, to understand some aspects of the organisation of the scientific projects.
About the volatility, in a Physical Science project the requirements could change over time for many different reasons:

listitem.para: the organizational complexity (and its evolution) is a cause of requirement volatility. Organizational goals, policies and roles of intended end users all may change during the development of the system; to keep this problem under control it is important to identify the right stakeholders within the organisation;

the requirements are the product of the contributions of many individuals, and these individuals often have conflicting needs and goals (different scientific objects within the same project); to keep this under control we have proposed a template in which we try to extract basic information from the scientific projects (using some basic steps of problem analysis);

increasing knowledge during the development: (i) people are learning/will learn new things during the development of the experiment, during prototyping activities or during testing and commissioning phases, and will learn during the operations; (ii) one of the most important cause of requirements volatility is that user needs evolve over time, because the science evolves over time thanks to new scientific discoveries (the advance of science) that could change the scientific objectives (and/or) the workflow of the project itself during the development. We have foreseen an iterative process.

section.title: Problem Analysis
section.para: The problem analysis is for OPFPS members and ICT stakeholders, to better understand the scientific project.

Due to the uniqueness of the scientific projects and the complexity of the problem domain, the problem analysis helps to manage the problems of scope and understanding, because they could strongly affect the requirement inception. In addition, the problem analysis could avoid or reduce presumptions (e.g. from OPFPS members that will analyze use cases).

The OPFPS members should analyse the information provided by the scientific stakeholders to understand if this is useful to define an effective solution. A key element of this analysis should ensure that “root causes,” not just the symptoms of the problem, are identified and subsequently addressed by the system.
Some aspects of the problem analysis of scientific project that could be useful in the OPFPS context are:

listitem.para: Try to find underlying causes of a problem to define measurable of a new solution. There is often a problem behind the problem or behind the current solution. It could be important to consists of finding underlying causes that may not be immediately apparent. Some key questions help in this process: why is it not profitable? Poor design? Too expensive? It is important to define which factors contribute to the problem and a way to measure the improvements.
